'''HAT-P-7b''' is an [[extrasolar planet]] discovered in 2008. It orbits very close to its parent star [[GSC 03547-01402]] and is larger than Jupiter due to the extreme heat it receives from its star. The dayside temperature is predicted to be 2730{{Â±|150|100}} K. The [[GSC 03547-01402]] system is within the [[field of view]] of the now operational [[Kepler Mission]] spacecraft,<ref>{{cite journal|id={{arxiv|0803.0746}}| title=HAT-P-7b: An Extremely Hot Massive Planet Transiting a Bright Star in the Kepler Field| author= Pal ''et al.''| journal=The [[Astrophysical Journal]]| year=2008| doi=10.1086/588010|volume=680| pages=1450 - 1456}}</ref> which confirmed the [[Methods of detecting extrasolar planets#Transit method|transit]] and orbital properties of the planet with significantly improved confidence, and observed [[occultation]] and light curve characteristics, consistent with a strongly absorbing atmosphere with limited [[advection]] to the night side.<ref name=KeplerScience>{{cite journal|title=Keplerâs Optical Phase Curve of the Exoplanet HAT-P-7b|journal=Science|date=2009-08-07|first=W.J.|last=Borucki|coauthors=D. Koch,1 J. Jenkins, D. Sasselov, R. Gilliland, N. Batalha, D. W. Latham,3 D. Caldwell, G. Basri, T. Brown,7 J. Christensen-Dalsgaard, W. D. Cochran, E. DeVore, E. Dunham, A. K. Dupree, T. Gautier, J. Geary, A. Gould, S. Howell, H. Kjeldsen, J. Lissauer, G. Marcy, S. Meibom, D. Morrison, J. Tarter|volume=325|issue=5941|pages=709|id= {{doi|10.1126/science.1178312}}|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/full/sci;325/5941/709|format=|accessdate=2009-08-07 }}</ref>
+
'''HAT-P-7b''' is an [[extrasolar planet]] discovered in 2008. It orbits very close to its parent star [[GSC 03547-01402]] and is larger than Jupiter. Due to the extreme heat it receives from its star, the dayside temperature is predicted to be 2730{{Â±|150|100}} K. The [[GSC 03547-01402]] system is within the [[field of view]] of the now operational [[Kepler Mission]] spacecraft,<ref>{{cite journal|id={{arxiv|0803.0746}}| title=HAT-P-7b: An Extremely Hot Massive Planet Transiting a Bright Star in the Kepler Field| author= Pal ''et al.''| journal=The [[Astrophysical Journal]]| year=2008| doi=10.1086/588010|volume=680| pages=1450 - 1456}}</ref> which confirmed the [[Methods of detecting extrasolar planets#Transit method|transit]] and orbital properties of the planet with significantly improved confidence, and observed [[occultation]] and light curve characteristics, consistent with a strongly absorbing atmosphere with limited [[advection]] to the night side.<ref name=KeplerScience>{{cite journal|title=Keplerâs Optical Phase Curve of the Exoplanet HAT-P-7b|journal=Science|date=2009-08-07|first=W.J.|last=Borucki|coauthors=D. Koch,1 J. Jenkins, D. Sasselov, R. Gilliland, N. Batalha, D. W. Latham,3 D. Caldwell, G. Basri, T. Brown,7 J. Christensen-Dalsgaard, W. D. Cochran, E. DeVore, E. Dunham, A. K. Dupree, T. Gautier, J. Geary, A. Gould, S. Howell, H. Kjeldsen, J. Lissauer, G. Marcy, S. Meibom, D. Morrison, J. Tarter|volume=325|issue=5941|pages=709|id= {{doi|10.1126/science.1178312}}|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/full/sci;325/5941/709|format=|accessdate=2009-08-07 }}</ref>
